```markdown # Policy for the Authorization and Licensing of Stablecoin Issuance in Finland under the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) **Policy ID:** FSA-POL-MiCA-001 **Version:** 1.0 **Effective Date:** [Date of Publication + 1 Month] **Approving Authority:** Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority (FIN-FSA) Board **Policy Owner:** FIN-FSA Digital Assets Division --- ## 1. Policy Title Authorization and Licensing Framework for Issuers of Asset-Referenced Tokens (ARTs) and E-Money Tokens (EMTs) in Finland ## 2. Purpose and Scope ### 2.1 Purpose This policy establishes a comprehensive framework for the authorization, licensing, and ongoing supervision of issuers of Asset-Referenced Tokens (ARTs) and E-Money Tokens (EMTs), collectively referred to as "stablecoins," operating within the Republic of Finland. Its primary purpose is to implement the requirements of Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 (Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation - MiCA) into national administrative practice, ensuring: * **Legal Certainty:** A clear and predictable authorization pathway for issuers. * **Financial Stability:** Mitigation of risks posed by stablecoins to the financial system. * **Consumer and Investor Protection:** Safeguarding of token-holders' rights and funds. * **Market Integrity:** Promotion of transparency, fairness, and robust governance in the crypto-asset market. ### 2.2 Scope This policy applies to: * All legal persons or other undertakings seeking authorization from the Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority (FIN-FSA) to issue ARTs or EMTs in the European Union, with their place of business or registered office in Finland. * Any entity offering stablecoins to the public within Finland or seeking admission of such tokens to trading on a regulated trading platform within Finland. * All ongoing operations of authorized issuers, including governance, capital management, reserve asset custody, and disclosure obligations. *This policy does not apply to crypto-asset services (e.g., custody, trading) which are covered under separate MiCA licensing regimes.* ## 3. Definitions | Term | Definition | | :--- | :--- | | **ART (Asset-Referenced Token)** | A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing another value or right, or a combination thereof, including one or more official currencies. | | **EMT (E-Money Token)** | A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing the value of one official currency. | | **Applicant** | A legal person formally applying to the FIN-FSA for authorization as an ART or EMT issuer. | | **Authorized Issuer** | An entity that has been granted a MiCA authorization by the FIN-FSA. | | **Reserve Assets** | The high-quality, liquid assets backing the value of the issued stablecoins, held in segregated accounts. | | **FIN-FSA** | The Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority (*Finanssivalvonta*). | | **MiCA** | Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 of the European Parliament and of the Council on Markets in Crypto-assets. | | **White Paper** | The mandatory disclosure document for an ART or EMT, as specified in MiCA. | ## 4. Policy Statement The Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority mandates that no entity may issue ARTs or EMTs to the public within Finland, or seek their admission to trading, without prior written authorization from the FIN-FSA. Authorization will only be granted to applicants that demonstrably meet and commit to maintaining all requirements set forth in MiCA and elaborated in this policy framework, including robust governance, sound capital and liquidity management, secure custody of reserve assets, transparent disclosure, and comprehensive consumer protection measures. ## 5. Procedures ### 5.1 Application for Authorization 1. **Pre-application Phase:** Prospective applicants are strongly encouraged to engage with the FIN-FSA's dedicated contact point for a preliminary, non-binding discussion. 2. **Formal Submission:** Applicants must submit a complete application dossier electronically via the FIN-FSA's secure portal, including: * Completed official application form. * A detailed business plan, including a three-year financial forecast. * The draft crypto-asset white paper for the ART/EMT. * Detailed descriptions of: * Governance arrangements (Board composition, fit & proper assessments). * Internal control mechanisms and risk management framework. * The custody policy for reserve assets. * The claims redemption policy. * Proof of initial capital (€350,000 for ART issuers; €150,000 for EMT issuers). * Program of operations. 3. **Application Fee:** A non-refundable administrative fee, as stipulated in national regulations, must be paid upon submission. 4. **Review Period:** The FIN-FSA will assess the application within **40 working days** of receipt of a complete dossier. This period may be extended for complex applications. 5. **Decision:** The FIN-FSA will issue a written decision to grant or refuse authorization. In case of refusal, detailed reasons will be provided. ### 5.2 Ongoing Operations & Supervision 1. **Reporting:** Authorized issuers must submit periodic reports (quarterly and annually) on reserve asset composition, liquidity, and operational risks, as per FIN-FSA templates. 2. **Material Change Notification:** Prior approval from the FIN-FSA is required for any material changes to the business model, governance, or the white paper. 3. **Incident Reporting:** Significant operational or security incidents affecting reserve assets or redemption rights must be reported to the FIN-FSA without undue delay, and no later than 24 hours after detection. ## 6. Compliance Requirements Authorized issuers must maintain continuous compliance with the following core MiCA requirements: | Area | Key Requirement | | :--- | :--- | | **Capital & Liquidity** | • Maintain permanent capital at or above the required minimum.
• Hold reserve assets in secure, segregated custody with a 1:1 ratio (plus a liquidity buffer for ARTs).
• Ensure reserve assets are invested in secure, low-risk instruments. | | **Governance** | • Establish a clear organizational structure with defined lines of responsibility.
• Ensure management bodies are of good repute and possess sufficient expertise (Fit & Proper).
• Implement effective internal controls, risk management, and compliance functions. | | **Consumer Protection** | • Publish and maintain a clear, fair, and not misleading white paper.
• Establish a secure, transparent, and timely redemption right for token-holders at par value.
• Provide clear, ongoing information to the public. | | **Data Protection** | • **Processing of Personal Data:** Issuers must comply with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (EU) 2016/679 and the Finnish Data Protection Act for any processing of personal data related to token holders, investors, or employees. This includes ensuring lawful basis for processing, implementing data security measures, respecting data subject rights, and conducting Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) where required. | | **Custody** | • Entrust reserve assets to a MiCA-authorized crypto-asset service provider (CASP) for custody, a credit institution, or an investment firm. | *Failure to comply with these requirements may result in supervisory measures, including fines, suspension of authorization, or withdrawal of authorization.* ## 7. Review and Update Schedule This policy shall be reviewed by the Policy Owner at least **annually**, or more frequently in response to: * Changes to EU or national legislation (including Level 2 and 3 measures under MiCA). * Significant shifts in market practice or risk. * Findings from the FIN-FSA's supervisory experience. Proposed amendments will be submitted for approval to the FIN-FSA Board. ## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements This policy directly implements and references the following legal acts: * **Primary Legislation:** Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 31 May 2023 on Markets in Crypto-assets (MiCA). * **National Framework:** Relevant national acts and decrees issued to complement MiCA's application in Finland (e.g., specifying administrative fees and procedural details). * **Data Protection:** Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (GDPR) and the Finnish Data Protection Act (1050/2018). *All authorized issuers are obligated to remain informed of the directly applicable EU regulations and any relevant regulatory technical standards (RTS) and implementing technical standards (ITS) developed by the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA).* ```

# Stablecoin Reserve Management and Asset Backing Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Stablecoin Reserve Management and Asset Backing Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes comprehensive requirements for the management, custody, and auditing of reserve assets backing issued stablecoins, ensuring full compliance with the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) and maintaining stability, transparency, and consumer protection.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
- All stablecoins issued by [Company Name]
- All personnel involved in reserve management, treasury operations, and compliance
- Third-party custodians, auditors, and service providers engaged in reserve-related activities
- All reserve assets held to back outstanding stablecoin liabilities

## 3. Definitions
- **Asset-Referenced Token (ART) / E-Money Token (EMT):** As defined under MiCA, referring to stablecoins issued by [Company Name].
- **High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA):** Assets that can be easily and immediately converted into cash at little or no loss of value, as further defined in Section 5.1.
- **Reserve Assets:** The total pool of assets held to fully back the value of all issued stablecoins.
- **Segregation of Reserves:** The legal and operational separation of reserve assets from the issuer's operating assets, ensuring they are held for the exclusive benefit of stablecoin holders.
- **Independent Auditor:** A qualified third-party audit firm with no material relationship to [Company Name], approved by the compliance department.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Company Name] is committed to maintaining a 1:1 backing for all issued stablecoins with a robust reserve of high-quality, liquid, and secure assets. All reserve assets will be held in segregated accounts, managed prudently, and subjected to regular independent audits to ensure continuous compliance with MiCA and the highest standards of transparency and risk management.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Eligible Reserve Assets & Concentration Limits
Reserve assets shall consist exclusively of **High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA)**:
- **Category 1 (Primary Reserves - Minimum 80%):**
    - Deposits at credit institutions.
    - Sovereign debt securities (e.g., EU Member State bonds, EEA government bonds) with a credit assessment of at least Credit Quality Step 2.
    - Short-term debt securities from high-quality issuers (e.g., supranational institutions, multilateral development banks).
- **Category 2 (Secondary Reserves - Maximum 20%):**
    - High-quality corporate bonds with a minimum credit rating of AA-.
    - Reverse repurchase agreements backed by Category 1 assets.
- **Concentration Limits:**
    - No single sovereign issuer (excluding EU/EEA aggregate): **Max 20%** of total reserves.
    - No single credit institution or corporate issuer: **Max 5%** of total reserves.
    - Assets must be denominated in the same currency as the referenced stablecoin or in currencies with deep, liquid FX markets.

### 5.2 Custody and Segregation Requirements
- **Legal Segregation:** Reserve assets must be legally segregated from the operational assets of [Company Name] on the issuer's balance sheet and held in bankruptcy-remote structures for the exclusive benefit of stablecoin holders.
- **Operational Custody:** All reserve assets must be held with regulated, reputable custodians (credit institutions or MiCA-authorized crypto-asset service providers for digital assets, if applicable).
    - Custodial agreements must explicitly acknowledge the segregated nature of the assets.
    - Daily reconciliation must occur between internal records and custodian statements.
- **Prohibition:** Reserve assets must not be pledged, re-hypothecated, or used as collateral for any purpose.

### 5.3 Liquidity Management
- **Liquidity Buffer:** A minimum of **10%** of total reserves must be held in overnight deposits or instruments maturing within 2 business days to meet potential immediate redemption requests.
- **Liquidity Stress Testing:** The Treasury Department must conduct monthly stress tests simulating scenarios of significant net redemptions (e.g., 20%, 40% of circulating supply within 7 days) to ensure the portfolio can meet obligations without fire sales.
- **Redemption Process:** A clear, publicly disclosed procedure for stablecoin holders to redeem tokens for the underlying reserve asset(s) or equivalent cash value must be maintained and executed promptly.

### 5.4 Independent Audit Procedures
- **Audit Frequency:** Full independent audits of the reserve holdings must be conducted **quarterly**, with a limited review performed monthly.
- **Auditor Selection:** The audit firm must be approved by the Board of Directors upon recommendation from the Audit & Risk Committee. Auditors are subject to rotation every five years.
- **Audit Scope:** The audit must verify:
    1. The existence, ownership, and valuation of all reserve assets.
    2. Compliance with the segregation requirements.
    3. The 1:1 ratio between the value of reserve assets and the outstanding stablecoins.
    4. Adherence to eligible asset types and concentration limits outlined in this policy.
- **Public Reporting:** A detailed report of the audit findings, including the composition and value of reserves as of the reporting date, must be published on the company's website within **14 days** of report completion.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
- The **Chief Financial Officer (CFO)** is the policy owner and is responsible for overall implementation.
- The **Treasury Department** is responsible for day-to-day reserve management, adherence to concentration limits, and liquidity management.
- The **Compliance Department** is responsible for monitoring regulatory developments (specifically MiCA), overseeing custodian due diligence, and ensuring audit timelines are met.
- Any breach of this policy must be reported immediately to the CFO and the Head of Compliance. Material breaches will be escalated to the Board of Directors.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
- **Annually** as part of the standard policy review cycle.
- **Immediately** upon any material change to MiCA's regulatory technical standards or implementing acts related to reserve assets.
- Following any material incident affecting the reserves.

All revisions require approval from the CFO and the Head of Compliance.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but not limited to, the following regulatory frameworks:
- **Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 (Markets in Crypto-Assets - MiCA):**
    - Article 36 (Reserve of assets for Asset-Referenced Tokens).
    - Article 48 (Reserve of assets for E-Money Tokens).
    - Requirements for HQLA composition, segregation, custody, and monthly/quarterly reporting and auditing as specified in the relevant Articles and delegated acts.
- Any subsequent Regulatory Technical Standards (RTS) or Implementing Acts published by the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) concerning reserve assets.

**Effective Date:** [Date]  
**Approved By:** [Name, Title]  
**Next Scheduled Review:** [Date, One Year from Effective Date]
```

# Stablecoin Consumer Protection and Disclosure Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Stablecoin Consumer Protection, Disclosure, and Redemption Rights Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to ensure that all communications, disclosures, and interactions with consumers regarding stablecoin products are clear, fair, and not misleading, in full compliance with the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) and related consumer protection legislation. The policy aims to protect consumers by ensuring they are fully informed about redemption rights, risks, fees, and procedures before, during, and after engaging with our stablecoin products.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All company personnel, including employees, contractors, and agents involved in the development, marketing, sale, or servicing of stablecoin products.
*   All communications channels, including but not limited to: websites, mobile applications, marketing materials, whitepapers, user agreements, and customer support interactions.
*   All stablecoin products issued or managed by the company, categorized as asset-referenced tokens or e-money tokens under MiCA.

## 3. Definitions
*   **Consumer:** Any natural person who is acting for purposes which are outside their trade, business, craft, or profession.
*   **Stablecoin:** A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing to the value of one or several fiat currencies, other crypto-assets, or a combination thereof.
*   **MiCA:** Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 31 May 2023 on Markets in Crypto-Assets.
*   **Key Information Document (KID):** A standardized, pre-contractual disclosure document required under MiCA for each stablecoin product.
*   **Redemption:** The right of a holder to redeem their stablecoins at par value for the referenced fiat currency or asset, as per the terms of issuance.
*   **Fair, Clear, and Not Misleading (FCNM):** The standard requiring information to be accurate, comprehensive, understandable, and presented in a way that does not deceive, omit material facts, or exaggerate benefits.

## 4. Policy Statement
It is the policy of [Company Name] to prioritize consumer protection in all aspects of its stablecoin operations. We are committed to providing all consumers with information that is **Fair, Clear, and Not Misleading (FCNM)**. This commitment encompasses transparent disclosure of all material terms, including but not limited to redemption rights and procedures, all associated costs and fees, and a balanced communication of potential risks and benefits. We will establish and maintain robust procedures to handle consumer complaints and inquiries effectively and promptly.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1. Standardized Disclosure Documents
1.  **Key Information Document (KID):** For each stablecoin product, a KID shall be drafted in accordance with the template and content requirements specified in MiCA Title II/III.
2.  **Content:** The KID must include, in a prominent section: the identity of the issuer, a clear description of the stablecoin's stabilizing mechanism, the rights attached to the token (especially redemption rights), the associated risks, the fee structure, and the complaint handling procedure.
3.  **Accessibility:** The KID must be provided to the consumer free of charge, in a durable medium, and **before** they are bound by any offer or contract. It must be published on the company's website in a machine-readable format.
4.  **Plain Language:** All disclosures must be written in clear, succinct, and comprehensible language, avoiding technical jargon where possible. Key warnings must be prominently displayed.

### 5.2. Redemption Procedures and Timelines
1.  **Clear Publication:** The detailed redemption procedure, including step-by-step instructions, required forms, and points of contact, shall be permanently published on the company's website.
2.  **Timelines:** The policy must explicitly state the maximum timeline for processing a redemption request, which shall not exceed the period stipulated by MiCA (e.g., standard redemption within [X] business days).
3.  **Fees:** Any fees applicable to redemption (including administrative fees or network fees) must be disclosed upfront in the KID and on the redemption interface. No hidden fees are permitted.
4.  **Suspension Protocol:** Procedures for the temporary suspension of redemptions (only under exceptional circumstances as defined by MiCA) must be documented, including internal authorization requirements and immediate public disclosure obligations.

### 5.3. Risk Communication Framework
1.  **Balanced Messaging:** All marketing and promotional materials must present a balanced view, ensuring that potential benefits are not emphasized without an equally prominent indication of risks.
2.  **Risk Warnings:** Standardized risk warnings must be developed for key risk categories (e.g., counterparty risk, reserve asset risk, technological risk, regulatory risk) and included in the KID and at key points in the consumer journey.
3.  **No Guarantees:** Communications must never state or imply that the value of the stablecoin is guaranteed or that investing is risk-free.

### 5.4. Complaint Handling Process

2.  **Accessible Channels:** Consumers shall be provided with easily accessible and free-of-charge channels to submit complaints (e.g., dedicated email, webform).

# Operational Resilience and Cybersecurity Policy for Stablecoin Infrastructure

## 1. Policy Title
**Operational Resilience and Cybersecurity Policy**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to ensure the operational resilience and cybersecurity of the stablecoin infrastructure. It is designed to protect the integrity, availability, and confidentiality of critical systems and data, ensuring continuity of service under adverse conditions, in alignment with regulatory expectations.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All personnel (employees, contractors, consultants, temporary staff).
*   All information systems, networks, data, and technology processes that support the issuance, management, transfer, and redemption of stablecoins.
*   All third-party service providers (including cloud providers, node operators, and key management services) that deliver material services to the stablecoin infrastructure.
*   All business units involved in the development, operation, and governance of the stablecoin ecosystem.

## 3. Definitions
*   **Critical Business Services (CBS):** Those services whose disruption would materially impact the stability of the stablecoin, cause significant financial loss, or severely harm customer trust.
*   **Impact Tolerance:** The maximum acceptable level of disruption to a Critical Business Service, defined in terms of maximum downtime and data loss.
*   **Major ICT-Related Incident:** An incident that has a significant impact on the continuity of Critical Business Services.
*   **Third-Party Service Provider (TSP):** Any external entity that provides ICT services supporting a Critical Business Service.
*   **Digital Operational Resilience:** The ability to build, assure, and review operational integrity and reliability by ensuring, through appropriate tools, controls, and procedures, the ICT-related capabilities required to withstand all types of ICT-related disruptions and threats.

## 4. Policy Statement
The organization is committed to maintaining a high level of operational resilience and cybersecurity for its stablecoin infrastructure. This requires the identification and protection of Critical Business Services, continuous testing of resilience capabilities, rapid and effective response to incidents, and robust planning for business continuity. All personnel and third-party providers are responsible for adhering to the principles and procedures outlined in this policy.

## 5. Procedures
### 5.1. Cybersecurity Controls and Testing
*   **Risk Management:** A dedicated ICT risk management framework shall be implemented, identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks to information assets and Critical Business Services.
*   **Security Controls:** Implement and maintain technical and organizational controls based on industry standards (e.g., ISO 27001, NIST CSF) including, but not limited to: access control, encryption, network security, vulnerability management, and secure software development lifecycle (SDLC).
*   **Resilience Testing:**
    *   **Vulnerability Assessments & Penetration Testing:** Conduct regular, at least annual, tests on all critical systems and after major changes.
    *   **Threat-Led Penetration Testing (TLPT):** In line with DORA, advanced TLPT shall be conducted on critical systems at least every three years, or after major changes.
    *   **Results Remediation:** All findings from tests must be logged, prioritized, and remediated within defined timeframes.

### 5.2. Incident Response Procedures
*   **Classification & Reporting:** A formal process shall classify ICT-related incidents based on severity. Major ICT-Related Incidents shall be reported internally immediately and to relevant competent authorities (e.g., Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority) as mandated by regulation.
*   **Response Plan:** A documented Incident Response Plan (IRP) shall outline roles, responsibilities, communication protocols, and containment/eradication/recovery procedures.
*   **Post-Incident Review:** All major incidents shall undergo a root cause analysis. Lessons learned shall be documented and used to improve controls and response capabilities.

### 5.3. Business Continuity Planning
*   **Business Impact Analysis (BIA):** A BIA shall be conducted to identify Critical Business Services and define their Impact Tolerances.
*   **Business Continuity Plans (BCP):** Documented BCPs shall be developed and maintained for each Critical Business Service, detailing recovery strategies, resources, and procedures to restore operations within their Impact Tolerance.
*   **Testing & Exercises:** BCPs shall be tested through table-top exercises and simulation tests at least annually to ensure their effectiveness.

### 5.4. Third-Party Service Provider Management
*   **Risk Assessment:** All TSPs supporting Critical Business Services shall undergo comprehensive due diligence and ongoing risk assessment prior to engagement.
*   **Contractual Requirements:** Contracts with TSPs must include clauses ensuring compliance with this policy, right to audit, security standards, incident notification obligations, and sub-contractor management.
*   **Concentration Risk:** The organization shall monitor and mitigate excessive reliance on a single TSP (concentration risk).
*   **Exit Strategies:** For critical TSPs, viable exit strategies and data portability plans must be documented and reviewed regularly.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   All personnel must complete mandatory cybersecurity and operational resilience awareness training annually.
*   Divisions and teams are responsible for implementing controls and procedures that satisfy this policy's requirements.
*   The Chief Technology Officer (CTO) or designated Head of Operational Resilience is responsible for overall policy implementation and oversight.
*   Non-compliance with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually,** as part of the standard governance cycle.
*   **Following a major incident** or significant test that reveals material weaknesses.
*   **Upon material changes** to the stablecoin infrastructure, business model, or applicable regulations.
*   **Whenever new regulatory guidelines** (EU or Finnish) are issued that impact operational resilience.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but is not limited to, the following regulatory frameworks:
*   **EU Regulation 2022/2554 (Digital Operational Resilience Act - DORA):** Providing the overarching EU framework for ICT risk management, incident reporting, resilience testing, TSP management, and information sharing.

## 1. Policy Title
Regulatory Reporting and Supervisory Engagement Policy under the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA)

## 2. Purpose and Scope

### 2.1 Purpose
The purpose of this policy is to establish a formal, consistent, and auditable framework for fulfilling all regulatory reporting obligations and managing supervisory engagements required under Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 (Markets in Crypto-Assets - MiCA) and related national legislation. This policy ensures timely, accurate, and complete submissions to the competent authority, the Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority (FIN-FSA), and promotes a culture of transparent and cooperative supervision.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All business units, subsidiaries, and employees of [Company Name] involved in the provision of MiCA-regulated crypto-asset services.
*   All activities that trigger reporting or notification requirements under MiCA.
*   All communications, both routine and ad-hoc, with the FIN-FSA and any other relevant competent authority.

## 3. Definitions

| Term | Definition |
| :--- | :--- |
| **Competent Authority** | The Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority (FIN-FSA), designated as the supervisory authority for MiCA implementation in Finland. |
| **Designated Reporting Officer (DRO)** | The individual(s) formally appointed with primary responsibility for the preparation, review, and submission of regulatory reports. |
| **Material Incident** | As defined under MiCA Article 80, any incident that has a significant impact on the financial performance or solvency of the firm, the continuity of its services, or the interests of its clients. This includes major operational or security disruptions. |
| **MiCA** | Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 31 May 2023 on markets in crypto-assets. |
| **Periodic Report** | Regular regulatory reports required under MiCA, including but not limited to financial reports, capital adequacy reports, and activity reports. |
| **Significant Incident Notification** | The mandatory, timely communication to the competent authority of any Material Incident. |

## 4. Policy Statement

[Company Name] is committed to full compliance with all reporting and transparency obligations under MiCA. The company will maintain open, professional, and constructive dialogue with the FIN-FSA. All reporting will be conducted with the highest standards of accuracy, completeness, and timeliness. Failure to adhere to this policy may result in disciplinary action, regulatory sanctions, and reputational damage.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Reporting Calendar and Requirements
*   The Compliance Department, in consultation with Finance and Risk, will maintain a **Master Regulatory Reporting Calendar**. This calendar will detail all periodic reporting deadlines, submission formats, and responsible officers.
*   The Calendar will be distributed quarterly to all DROs and senior management, and updated immediately upon notification of any new or changed requirement.
*   Periodic reports (e.g., financial, prudential) must be drafted, reviewed, and approved according to the internal timeline stipulated in the Calendar, allowing for a minimum 5-business-day buffer prior to the regulatory deadline.

### 5.2 Designated Reporting Officers (DROs)
*   The Chief Compliance Officer (CCO) shall appoint primary and secondary DROs for each report type. Appointments will be documented and communicated to the FIN-FSA upon request.
*   DROs are responsible for:
    *   Data collection and validation from relevant business units.
    *   Drafting the report in the prescribed format.
    *   Obtaining necessary internal approvals (see Section 5.4).
    *   Submitting the final report via the FIN-FSA's official channels.
    *   Maintaining a complete audit trail of data, drafts, and submissions.

### 5.3 Incident Notification Procedures
1.  **Identification:** Any employee who identifies a potential Material Incident must immediately notify their line manager and the CCO.
2.  **Assessment:** The CCO will convene an incident response team (including Legal, IT Security, and Risk) to assess the incident against MiCA criteria (Article 80) within **2 hours** of initial notification.
3.  **Notification:** If deemed reportable, the CCO (or delegate) shall notify the FIN-FSA **without undue delay** and in any event **no later than 24 hours** after becoming aware of the incident. The initial notification may be in summary form.
4.  **Follow-up:** A detailed written report, outlining the incident's cause, impact, and remedial actions, shall be submitted to the FIN-FSA within **7 calendar days** of the initial notification.

### 5.4 Supervisory Communication Protocols
*   **Single Point of Contact:** The CCO (or a specifically appointed Head of Regulatory Affairs) is the primary point of contact for all routine supervisory communications with the FIN-FSA.
*   **Formal Requests:** All formal information requests, questionnaires, or inquiries from the FIN-FSA must be directed to the CCO. The CCO will log the request, coordinate the response, and ensure it is submitted by the deadline.
*   **On-Site Inspections:** In the event of an on-site inspection by the FIN-FSA, the CCO will lead the coordination, including providing workspace, requested documentation, and facilitating interviews. All employees must cooperate fully and truthfully with inspectors.
*   **Record Keeping:** A log of all substantive communications with the FIN-FSA (meetings, calls, emails, submissions) shall be maintained by the Compliance Department indefinitely.

## 6. Compliance Requirements

*   All employees must complete annual training on this policy and MiCA reporting obligations.
*   The Compliance Department will conduct quarterly spot-checks on report preparation processes and data sources.
*   Any actual or suspected breach of this policy (e.g., missed deadline, inaccurate data) must be reported immediately to the CCO and will be investigated. Breaches may be considered a disciplinary matter.

*   **Annually** by the Compliance Department and the Legal Department.
*   **Immediately** following any material change to MiCA or related FIN-FSA guidance.

# Stablecoin Reserve Management and Asset Backing Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Stablecoin Reserve Management and Asset Backing Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes comprehensive requirements for the management, custody, and auditing of reserve assets backing issued stablecoins, ensuring full compliance with the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) and maintaining stability, transparency, and consumer protection.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
- All stablecoins issued by [Company Name]
- All personnel involved in reserve management, treasury operations, and compliance
- Third-party custodians, auditors, and service providers engaged in reserve-related activities
- All reserve assets held to back outstanding stablecoin liabilities

## 3. Definitions
- **Asset-Referenced Token (ART) / E-Money Token (EMT):** As defined under MiCA, referring to stablecoins issued by [Company Name].
- **High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA):** Assets that can be easily and immediately converted into cash at little or no loss of value, as further defined in Section 5.1.
- **Reserve Assets:** The total pool of assets held to fully back the value of all issued stablecoins.
- **Segregation of Reserves:** The legal and operational separation of reserve assets from the issuer's operating assets, ensuring they are held for the exclusive benefit of stablecoin holders.
- **Independent Auditor:** A qualified third-party audit firm with no material relationship to [Company Name], approved by the compliance department.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Company Name] is committed to maintaining a 1:1 backing for all issued stablecoins with a robust reserve of high-quality, liquid, and secure assets. All reserve assets will be held in segregated accounts, managed prudently, and subjected to regular independent audits to ensure continuous compliance with MiCA and the highest standards of transparency and risk management.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Eligible Reserve Assets & Concentration Limits
Reserve assets shall consist exclusively of **High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA)**:
- **Category 1 (Primary Reserves - Minimum 80%):**
    - Deposits at credit institutions.
    - Sovereign debt securities (e.g., EU Member State bonds, EEA government bonds) with a credit assessment of at least Credit Quality Step 2.
    - Short-term debt securities from high-quality issuers (e.g., supranational institutions, multilateral development banks).
- **Category 2 (Secondary Reserves - Maximum 20%):**
    - High-quality corporate bonds with a minimum credit rating of AA-.
    - Reverse repurchase agreements backed by Category 1 assets.
- **Concentration Limits:**
    - No single sovereign issuer (excluding EU/EEA aggregate): **Max 20%** of total reserves.
    - No single credit institution or corporate issuer: **Max 5%** of total reserves.
    - Assets must be denominated in the same currency as the referenced stablecoin or in currencies with deep, liquid FX markets.

### 5.2 Custody and Segregation Requirements
- **Legal Segregation:** Reserve assets must be legally segregated from the operational assets of [Company Name] on the issuer's balance sheet and held in bankruptcy-remote structures for the exclusive benefit of stablecoin holders.
- **Operational Custody:** All reserve assets must be held with regulated, reputable custodians (credit institutions or MiCA-authorized crypto-asset service providers for digital assets, if applicable).
    - Custodial agreements must explicitly acknowledge the segregated nature of the assets.
    - Daily reconciliation must occur between internal records and custodian statements.
- **Prohibition:** Reserve assets must not be pledged, re-hypothecated, or used as collateral for any purpose.

### 5.3 Liquidity Management
- **Liquidity Buffer:** A minimum of **10%** of total reserves must be held in overnight deposits or instruments maturing within 2 business days to meet potential immediate redemption requests.
- **Liquidity Stress Testing:** The Treasury Department must conduct monthly stress tests simulating scenarios of significant net redemptions (e.g., 20%, 40% of circulating supply within 7 days) to ensure the portfolio can meet obligations without fire sales.
- **Redemption Process:** A clear, publicly disclosed procedure for stablecoin holders to redeem tokens for the underlying reserve asset(s) or equivalent cash value must be maintained and executed promptly.

### 5.4 Independent Audit Procedures
- **Audit Frequency:** Full independent audits of the reserve holdings must be conducted **quarterly**, with a limited review performed monthly.
- **Auditor Selection:** The audit firm must be approved by the Board of Directors upon recommendation from the Audit & Risk Committee. Auditors are subject to rotation every five years.
- **Audit Scope:** The audit must verify:
    1. The existence, ownership, and valuation of all reserve assets.
    2. Compliance with the segregation requirements.
    3. The 1:1 ratio between the value of reserve assets and the outstanding stablecoins.
    4. Adherence to eligible asset types and concentration limits outlined in this policy.
- **Public Reporting:** A detailed report of the audit findings, including the composition and value of reserves as of the reporting date, must be published on the company's website within **14 days** of report completion.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
- The **Chief Financial Officer (CFO)** is the policy owner and is responsible for overall implementation.
- The **Treasury Department** is responsible for day-to-day reserve management, adherence to concentration limits, and liquidity management.
- The **Compliance Department** is responsible for monitoring regulatory developments (specifically MiCA), overseeing custodian due diligence, and ensuring audit timelines are met.
- Any breach of this policy must be reported immediately to the CFO and the Head of Compliance. Material breaches will be escalated to the Board of Directors.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
- **Annually** as part of the standard policy review cycle.
- **Immediately** upon any material change to MiCA's regulatory technical standards or implementing acts related to reserve assets.
- Following any material incident affecting the reserves.

All revisions require approval from the CFO and the Head of Compliance.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but not limited to, the following regulatory frameworks:
- **Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 (Markets in Crypto-Assets - MiCA):**
    - Article 36 (Reserve of assets for Asset-Referenced Tokens).
    - Article 48 (Reserve of assets for E-Money Tokens).
    - Requirements for HQLA composition, segregation, custody, and monthly/quarterly reporting and auditing as specified in the relevant Articles and delegated acts.
- Any subsequent Regulatory Technical Standards (RTS) or Implementing Acts published by the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) concerning reserve assets.

# Stablecoin Consumer Protection and Disclosure Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Stablecoin Consumer Protection, Disclosure, and Redemption Rights Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to ensure that all communications, disclosures, and interactions with consumers regarding stablecoin products are clear, fair, and not misleading, in full compliance with the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) and related consumer protection legislation. The policy aims to protect consumers by ensuring they are fully informed about redemption rights, risks, fees, and procedures before, during, and after engaging with our stablecoin products.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All company personnel, including employees, contractors, and agents involved in the development, marketing, sale, or servicing of stablecoin products.
*   All communications channels, including but not limited to: websites, mobile applications, marketing materials, whitepapers, user agreements, and customer support interactions.
*   All stablecoin products issued or managed by the company, categorized as asset-referenced tokens or e-money tokens under MiCA.

## 3. Definitions
*   **Consumer:** Any natural person who is acting for purposes which are outside their trade, business, craft, or profession.
*   **Stablecoin:** A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing to the value of one or several fiat currencies, other crypto-assets, or a combination thereof.
*   **MiCA:** Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 31 May 2023 on Markets in Crypto-Assets.
*   **Key Information Document (KID):** A standardized, pre-contractual disclosure document required under MiCA for each stablecoin product.
*   **Redemption:** The right of a holder to redeem their stablecoins at par value for the referenced fiat currency or asset, as per the terms of issuance.
*   **Fair, Clear, and Not Misleading (FCNM):** The standard requiring information to be accurate, comprehensive, understandable, and presented in a way that does not deceive, omit material facts, or exaggerate benefits.

## 4. Policy Statement
It is the policy of [Company Name] to prioritize consumer protection in all aspects of its stablecoin operations. We are committed to providing all consumers with information that is **Fair, Clear, and Not Misleading (FCNM)**. This commitment encompasses transparent disclosure of all material terms, including but not limited to redemption rights and procedures, all associated costs and fees, and a balanced communication of potential risks and benefits. We will establish and maintain robust procedures to handle consumer complaints and inquiries effectively and promptly.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1. Standardized Disclosure Documents
1.  **Key Information Document (KID):** For each stablecoin product, a KID shall be drafted in accordance with the template and content requirements specified in MiCA Title II/III.
2.  **Content:** The KID must include, in a prominent section: the identity of the issuer, a clear description of the stablecoin's stabilizing mechanism, the rights attached to the token (especially redemption rights), the associated risks, the fee structure, and the complaint handling procedure.
3.  **Accessibility:** The KID must be provided to the consumer free of charge, in a durable medium, and **before** they are bound by any offer or contract. It must be published on the company's website in a machine-readable format.
4.  **Plain Language:** All disclosures must be written in clear, succinct, and comprehensible language, avoiding technical jargon where possible. Key warnings must be prominently displayed.

### 5.2. Redemption Procedures and Timelines
1.  **Clear Publication:** The detailed redemption procedure, including step-by-step instructions, required forms, and points of contact, shall be permanently published on the company's website.
2.  **Timelines:** The policy must explicitly state the maximum timeline for processing a redemption request, which shall not exceed the period stipulated by MiCA (e.g., standard redemption within [X] business days).
3.  **Fees:** Any fees applicable to redemption (including administrative fees or network fees) must be disclosed upfront in the KID and on the redemption interface. No hidden fees are permitted.
4.  **Suspension Protocol:** Procedures for the temporary suspension of redemptions (only under exceptional circumstances as defined by MiCA) must be documented, including internal authorization requirements and immediate public disclosure obligations.

### 5.3. Risk Communication Framework
1.  **Balanced Messaging:** All marketing and promotional materials must present a balanced view, ensuring that potential benefits are not emphasized without an equally prominent indication of risks.
2.  **Risk Warnings:** Standardized risk warnings must be developed for key risk categories (e.g., counterparty risk, reserve asset risk, technological risk, regulatory risk) and included in the KID and at key points in the consumer journey.
3.  **No Guarantees:** Communications must never state or imply that the value of the stablecoin is guaranteed or that investing is risk-free.

### 5.4. Complaint Handling Process
1.  **Designated Function:** The Compliance Department shall oversee the complaint handling process.
2.  **Accessible Channels:** Consumers shall be provided with easily accessible and free-of-charge channels to submit complaints (e.g., dedicated email, webform).
3.  **Acknowledgement & Resolution:** All complaints shall be acknowledged in writing within 10 business days of receipt. The company shall investigate and strive to provide a substantive response addressing the issues raised within [X] business days, as per regulatory deadlines.
4.  **Record Keeping:** A log of all consumer complaints, including their nature, resolution, and response time, shall be maintained for a minimum of five years for regulatory examination.
5.  **Escalation:** Consumers shall be informed of their right to escalate unresolved complaints to the relevant national competent authority.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   All staff must complete mandatory annual training on this policy and MiCA's consumer protection provisions.
*   The Legal and Compliance Department is responsible for reviewing and approving all consumer-facing documentation for FCNM compliance prior to publication.
*   Marketing campaigns for stablecoin products require pre-approval from Compliance to ensure adherence to the Risk Communication Framework.
*   Failure to comply with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or engagement.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually,** as part of the company's standard policy review cycle.
*   **Immediately,** following any material change in regulatory requirements (e.g., updates to MiCA Level 2 measures).
*   **As needed,** following a material incident related to consumer protection or identified deficiency in the policy's operation.

The Chief Compliance Officer (CCO) is the owner of this policy and is responsible for its maintenance.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but not limited to, the following regulatory frameworks:
*   **Primary Reference:** Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 (MiCA), specifically:
    *   Article 14(1): Obligation to act honestly, fairly, and professionally.
    *   Article 15(1)-(3): General duty to provide fair, clear, and not misleading information.
    *   Articles 31-33 & 48-50: Specific pre-contractual disclosure and KID requirements for asset-referenced tokens and e-money tokens.
    *   Articles 34 & 51: Specific rules on redemption rights and procedures.
    *   Article 77: Complaint handling procedures.
*   **Supplementary Guidance:** Any relevant regulatory technical standards (RTS) and implementing technical standards (ITS) issued by the European Banking Authority (EBA) and European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) under MiCA.
*   **National Law:** Relevant consumer protection laws in jurisdictions where the company operates.

Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing Policy for Stablecoin Services

### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to prevent, detect, and report money laundering and terrorist financing activities related to stablecoin operations. - All stablecoin issuance, redemption, transfer, and exchange services
- All customer relationships and transactions involving stablecoins
- All business units and subsidiaries engaged in crypto-asset services

- **Customer Due Diligence (CDD)**: The process of identifying and verifying customers and beneficial owners
- **Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD)**: Additional measures for higher-risk customers and transactions
- **Politically Exposed Person (PEP)**: Individuals entrusted with prominent public functions
- **Stablecoin**: A type of crypto-asset that aims to maintain a stable value relative to a specified asset or pool of assets
- **Suspicious Activity Report (SAR)**: A report filed with the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) of Finland regarding suspicious transactions

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Risk-Based Customer Due Diligence
#### 5.1.1 Standard CDD Measures
- Identify and verify customer identity using reliable, independent source documents
- Identify and verify beneficial owners holding 25% or more ownership/control
- Understand the purpose and intended nature of the business relationship
- Conduct ongoing monitoring of the business relationship

- PEPs, their family members, and close associates
- Customers from high-risk third countries
- Complex or unusually large transactions
- Situations where the customer's risk profile is determined to be high

May be applied only where the customer presents a low risk of money laundering/terrorist financing, in accordance with regulatory guidelines.

- Document all investigations and findings

- Employees must immediately report suspicious activities to the AML Compliance Officer

- Keep transaction records for at least five years after the transaction is completed
- Ensure records are readily available to competent authorities upon request

#### 5.4.2 Record Security
- Implement secure electronic storage with appropriate access controls
- Maintain backup systems to prevent data loss
- Ensure records are protected against unauthorized alteration

- Include stablecoin-specific risks and typologies in training materials

# Stablecoin Governance, Risk Management, and Internal Control Policy

## 1. Policy Title
**Stablecoin Issuance and Operations: Governance, Risk Management, and Internal Control Framework**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive governance, risk management, and internal control framework to ensure the safe, sound, and compliant issuance and management of stablecoin activities. It is designed to meet the requirements of the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA) and to protect the interests of users, stakeholders, and the integrity of the financial system.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to all activities related to the issuance, redemption, management, and operational support of stablecoins by [Company Name]. It is binding for:
*   The Board of Directors and its committees.
*   All senior management and executive leadership.
*   All employees, contractors, and third-party service providers involved in stablecoin operations.
*   All associated technological infrastructure, reserve management activities, and partner relationships.

## 3. Definitions
*   **Board:** The Board of Directors of [Company Name].
*   **Governance Framework:** The system of rules, practices, and processes by which the company is directed and controlled.
*   **MiCA:** Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 on Markets in Crypto-Assets.
*   **Operational Risk:** The risk of loss resulting from inadequate or failed internal processes, people, systems, or external events.
*   **Liquidity Risk:** The risk that the issuer cannot meet redemption requests promptly and at par value due to insufficient liquid assets.
*   **Market Risk:** The risk of losses in the reserve assets backing the stablecoin due to movements in market prices (e.g., interest rates, FX rates, asset prices).
*   **Internal Controls:** Processes designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the effectiveness and efficiency of operations, reliability of financial reporting, and compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
*   **Stablecoin:** A type of crypto-asset that purports to maintain a stable value by referencing to the value of an official currency.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Company Name] is committed to the highest standards of governance, prudence, and transparency in its stablecoin operations. The company will maintain a robust, three-lines-of-defense model to ensure effective risk management and control:
1.  **First Line (Business & Operations):** Management ownership and implementation of controls.
2.  **Second Line (Oversight):** Independent risk and compliance functions providing challenge and oversight.
3.  **Third Line (Independent Assurance):** Internal Audit providing independent verification.

The Board bears ultimate responsibility for the oversight of this framework.

# Operational Resilience and Cybersecurity Policy for Stablecoin Infrastructure

## 1. Policy Title
**Operational Resilience and Cybersecurity Policy**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to ensure the operational resilience and cybersecurity of the stablecoin infrastructure. It is designed to protect the integrity, availability, and confidentiality of critical systems and data, ensuring continuity of service under adverse conditions, in alignment with regulatory expectations.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All personnel (employees, contractors, consultants, temporary staff).
*   All information systems, networks, data, and technology processes that support the issuance, management, transfer, and redemption of stablecoins.
*   All third-party service providers (including cloud providers, node operators, and key management services) that deliver material services to the stablecoin infrastructure.
*   All business units involved in the development, operation, and governance of the stablecoin ecosystem.

## 3. Definitions
*   **Critical Business Services (CBS):** Those services whose disruption would materially impact the stability of the stablecoin, cause significant financial loss, or severely harm customer trust.
*   **Impact Tolerance:** The maximum acceptable level of disruption to a Critical Business Service, defined in terms of maximum downtime and data loss.
*   **Major ICT-Related Incident:** An incident that has a significant impact on the continuity of Critical Business Services.
*   **Third-Party Service Provider (TSP):** Any external entity that provides ICT services supporting a Critical Business Service.
*   **Digital Operational Resilience:** The ability to build, assure, and review operational integrity and reliability by ensuring, through appropriate tools, controls, and procedures, the ICT-related capabilities required to withstand all types of ICT-related disruptions and threats.

## 4. Policy Statement
The organization is committed to maintaining a high level of operational resilience and cybersecurity for its stablecoin infrastructure. This requires the identification and protection of Critical Business Services, continuous testing of resilience capabilities, rapid and effective response to incidents, and robust planning for business continuity. All personnel and third-party providers are responsible for adhering to the principles and procedures outlined in this policy.

## 5. Procedures
### 5.1. Cybersecurity Controls and Testing
*   **Risk Management:** A dedicated ICT risk management framework shall be implemented, identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks to information assets and Critical Business Services.
*   **Security Controls:** Implement and maintain technical and organizational controls based on industry standards (e.g., ISO 27001, NIST CSF) including, but not limited to: access control, encryption, network security, vulnerability management, and secure software development lifecycle (SDLC).
*   **Resilience Testing:**
    *   **Vulnerability Assessments & Penetration Testing:** Conduct regular, at least annual, tests on all critical systems and after major changes.
    *   **Threat-Led Penetration Testing (TLPT):** In line with DORA, advanced TLPT shall be conducted on critical systems at least every three years, or after major changes.
    *   **Results Remediation:** All findings from tests must be logged, prioritized, and remediated within defined timeframes.

### 5.2. Incident Response Procedures
*   **Classification & Reporting:** A formal process shall classify ICT-related incidents based on severity. Major ICT-Related Incidents shall be reported internally immediately and to relevant competent authorities (e.g., Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority) as mandated by regulation.
*   **Response Plan:** A documented Incident Response Plan (IRP) shall outline roles, responsibilities, communication protocols, and containment/eradication/recovery procedures.
*   **Post-Incident Review:** All major incidents shall undergo a root cause analysis. Lessons learned shall be documented and used to improve controls and response capabilities.

### 5.3. Business Continuity Planning
*   **Business Impact Analysis (BIA):** A BIA shall be conducted to identify Critical Business Services and define their Impact Tolerances.
*   **Business Continuity Plans (BCP):** Documented BCPs shall be developed and maintained for each Critical Business Service, detailing recovery strategies, resources, and procedures to restore operations within their Impact Tolerance.
*   **Testing & Exercises:** BCPs shall be tested through table-top exercises and simulation tests at least annually to ensure their effectiveness.

### 5.4. Third-Party Service Provider Management
*   **Risk Assessment:** All TSPs supporting Critical Business Services shall undergo comprehensive due diligence and ongoing risk assessment prior to engagement.
*   **Contractual Requirements:** Contracts with TSPs must include clauses ensuring compliance with this policy, right to audit, security standards, incident notification obligations, and sub-contractor management.
*   **Concentration Risk:** The organization shall monitor and mitigate excessive reliance on a single TSP (concentration risk).
*   **Exit Strategies:** For critical TSPs, viable exit strategies and data portability plans must be documented and reviewed regularly.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   All personnel must complete mandatory cybersecurity and operational resilience awareness training annually.
*   Divisions and teams are responsible for implementing controls and procedures that satisfy this policy's requirements.
*   The Chief Technology Officer (CTO) or designated Head of Operational Resilience is responsible for overall policy implementation and oversight.
*   Non-compliance with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually,** as part of the standard governance cycle.
*   **Following a major incident** or significant test that reveals material weaknesses.
*   **Upon material changes** to the stablecoin infrastructure, business model, or applicable regulations.
*   **Whenever new regulatory guidelines** (EU or Finnish) are issued that impact operational resilience.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to ensure compliance with, but is not limited to, the following regulatory frameworks:
*   **EU Regulation 2022/2554 (Digital Operational Resilience Act - DORA):** Providing the overarching EU framework for ICT risk management, incident reporting, resilience testing, TSP management, and information sharing.
*   **Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority (FIN-FSA) Regulations & Guidelines:** Including relevant provisions from the Act on the Financial Supervisory Authority, and FIN-FSA's guidelines and statements on operational risk, IT security, and continuity management for financial market participants.
*   **Other Applicable Laws:** General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), Finnish National Security and Cybersecurity Legislation.

*   All business units, subsidiaries, and employees of [Company Name] involved in the provision of MiCA-regulated crypto-asset services.
*   All activities that trigger reporting or notification requirements under MiCA.
*   All communications, both routine and ad-hoc, with the FIN-FSA and any other relevant competent authority.

## 3. Definitions

| Term | Definition |
| :--- | :--- |
| **Competent Authority** | The Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority (FIN-FSA), designated as the supervisory authority for MiCA implementation in Finland. |
| **Designated Reporting Officer (DRO)** | The individual(s) formally appointed with primary responsibility for the preparation, review, and submission of regulatory reports. |
| **Material Incident** | As defined under MiCA Article 80, any incident that has a significant impact on the financial performance or solvency of the firm, the continuity of its services, or the interests of its clients. This includes major operational or security disruptions. |
| **MiCA** | Regulation (EU) 2023/1114 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 31 May 2023 on markets in crypto-assets. |
| **Periodic Report** | Regular regulatory reports required under MiCA, including but not limited to financial reports, capital adequacy reports, and activity reports. |
| **Significant Incident Notification** | The mandatory, timely communication to the competent authority of any Material Incident. |

## 4. Policy Statement

[Company Name] is committed to full compliance with all reporting and transparency obligations under MiCA. The company will maintain open, professional, and constructive dialogue with the FIN-FSA. All reporting will be conducted with the highest standards of accuracy, completeness, and timeliness. Failure to adhere to this policy may result in disciplinary action, regulatory sanctions, and reputational damage.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Reporting Calendar and Requirements
*   The Compliance Department, in consultation with Finance and Risk, will maintain a **Master Regulatory Reporting Calendar**. This calendar will detail all periodic reporting deadlines, submission formats, and responsible officers.
*   The Calendar will be distributed quarterly to all DROs and senior management, and updated immediately upon notification of any new or changed requirement.
*   Periodic reports (e.g., financial, prudential) must be drafted, reviewed, and approved according to the internal timeline stipulated in the Calendar, allowing for a minimum 5-business-day buffer prior to the regulatory deadline.

### 5.2 Designated Reporting Officers (DROs)
*   The Chief Compliance Officer (CCO) shall appoint primary and secondary DROs for each report type. Appointments will be documented and communicated to the FIN-FSA upon request.
*   DROs are responsible for:
    *   Data collection and validation from relevant business units.
    *   Drafting the report in the prescribed format.
    *   Obtaining necessary internal approvals (see Section 5.4).
    *   Submitting the final report via the FIN-FSA's official channels.
    *   Maintaining a complete audit trail of data, drafts, and submissions.

### 5.3 Incident Notification Procedures
1.  **Identification:** Any employee who identifies a potential Material Incident must immediately notify their line manager and the CCO.
2.  **Assessment:** The CCO will convene an incident response team (including Legal, IT Security, and Risk) to assess the incident against MiCA criteria (Article 80) within **2 hours** of initial notification.
3.  **Notification:** If deemed reportable, the CCO (or delegate) shall notify the FIN-FSA **without undue delay** and in any event **no later than 24 hours** after becoming aware of the incident. The initial notification may be in summary form.
4.  **Follow-up:** A detailed written report, outlining the incident's cause, impact, and remedial actions, shall be submitted to the FIN-FSA within **7 calendar days** of the initial notification.

*   **Single Point of Contact:** The CCO (or a specifically appointed Head of Regulatory Affairs) is the primary point of contact for all routine supervisory communications with the FIN-FSA.
*   **Formal Requests:** All formal information requests, questionnaires, or inquiries from the FIN-FSA must be directed to the CCO. The CCO will log the request, coordinate the response, and ensure it is submitted by the deadline.
*   **On-Site Inspections:** In the event of an on-site inspection by the FIN-FSA, the CCO will lead the coordination, including providing workspace, requested documentation, and facilitating interviews. All employees must cooperate fully and truthfully with inspectors.
*   **Record Keeping:** A log of all substantive communications with the FIN-FSA (meetings, calls, emails, submissions) shall be maintained by the Compliance Department indefinitely.

*   The Compliance Department will conduct quarterly spot-checks on report preparation processes and data sources.
*   Any actual or suspected breach of this policy (e.g., missed deadline, inaccurate data) must be reported immediately to the CCO and will be investigated. Breaches may be considered a disciplinary matter.
*   Adherence to this policy will be a key component of the relevant employees' performance assessments.

This policy shall be reviewed:
*   **Annually** by the Compliance Department and the Legal Department.
*   **Immediately** following any material change to MiCA or related FIN-FSA guidance.
*   Following any significant internal control failure related to regulatory reporting.
